text: I found this video <https://youtu.be/3TqN_M1L4ts> and I was amazed that the first 40 min demo/explanation from Swift could have been almost a copy/paste from a Julia demo. Someone from the audience asked "Why Swift and not Julia?" and the explanation just sounded like BS to me (but of course I am biased). Chris Lattner says that Swift syntax is similar to python, which is true for those first 40 min ... after his explanation about compilers ... the code starts to become messy and less readable in my opinion. So ... I still don't understand why Swift was chosen for TF by Google and why they keep saying that Julia is less mature.

elements.text: I found this video

and I was amazed that the first 40 min demo/explanation from Swift could have been almost a copy/paste from a Julia demo. Someone from the audience asked "Why Swift and not Julia?" and the explanation just sounded like BS to me (but of course I am biased). Chris Lattner says that Swift syntax is similar to python, which is true for those first 40 min ... after his explanation about compilers ... the code starts to become messy and less readable in my opinion. So ... I still don't understand why Swift was chosen for TF by Google and why they keep saying that Julia is less mature.

text:
Long game Swift Diff Prog work is a fantastic win for us.
We are (and were) doing diff prog *regardless* of what they are doing.
They are very smart people and we can (and do) absolutely steal their ideas.
They have huge branding presence that is going to grow the space.
Its not a zero sum game, in fact its the opposite with them entering the field. (Less so for Python I feel).
the Swift work creates more users/developers for diff prog in general.
So if say 10x as many people become interested in it, that is a win.
A smaller portion of a way bigger pie is still more pie at the end of the day.
Its not like some large portion of existing julia users would go to swift.
Infact, odds are a lot of people who start doing diff prog in Swift will end up in julia,
*because* we can do more interesting diff prog problems, since we have a whole world of constraint optimizers, diffeq solvers, a numerical toolbox that swift will never catch up on.
Even things like plotting and dataframes had to be built by the swift teams.
they are not attracting random university researchers  to implement new papers in swift.
Sure you can do diff prog in swift for some iOS game you want to make, or maybe even to optimise some network communication protocol.
but thats not going to let you build the next generation of pharmosuticals,
its not going to let you optimize power production to reduce emissions, its not going let you understand migration patterns of endangered species.
We are playing with the same pieces, but its a whole different boardgame.

So we do our thing, and   meanwhile, they do their thing.
Having good ideas and publishing them.
and   massively increase awareness.
We are not in a competion

and   massively increase awareness.
We are not in a competion

"diff prog in swift for some iOS game you want to make, or maybe even to optimise some network communication protocol."

Those have much more potential users, and are the types of use case that can revolutionize programming. I think it would be a shame if we just yielded them

I want my time spent on the ones that revolutionalize science and save the world.

text:
<@U6A936746> i get what you're saying, but for me it's more personal. In a sense, I staked my career on Julia. I learned python first, but started picking up Julia in 2014 when I saw its potential. I can only use it at work because I help run a startup....but all that had opportunity cost- I could have been learning swift, getting better at python etc

So if the startup doesn't work out, my investment in Julia will be far more helpful (and my career more secure) if Julia becomes ubiquitous. This includes its use in any future grad program I might want to attend.

Also some things are harder to steal - running first class on mobile, anything that uses static typing (including shape and index checking like in dex.

elements.text:
i get what you're saying, but for me it's more personal. In a sense, I staked my career on Julia. I learned python first, but started picking up Julia in 2014 when I saw its potential. I can only use it at work because I help run a startup....but all that had opportunity cost- I could have been learning swift, getting better at python etc

So if the startup doesn't work out, my investment in Julia will be far more helpful (and my career more secure) if Julia becomes ubiquitous. This includes its use in any future grad program I might want to attend.

Also some things are harder to steal - running first class on mobile, anything that uses static typing (including shape and index checking like in dex.

text:
Friend, you think that all doesn’t apply to me also?
I started picking up julia in Dec 2014.
I work full-time programming in Julia; basically have done so since then first in my PhD and now in industry.
Literally the only languages I can program now are Julia and Dex.
(I tried python again last yet, it was … embarassing)
I have a lot of niche and non-trivially transferable skills.
(A lot that are are transferable also though. Soft-skills really matter far more, can alway learn a new language)

Acting like their gain is our loss tends to make us look like rabid fanatics.
Which is counter to the goal.
Being chill and making space at the table, makes us look confident, and gets us friends.
(and we should be confident, we’re great at what we do)

text: <@U6A936746> Small clarification here ... It's not that their gain is _our_ loss, it's actually _their_ loss because they are wasting precious time and effort on the other stuff instead on the cool stuff, i.e. Julia. And as a person that always wants the most optimal result ... well ... feels like a loss for everyone.  I understand what you are saying we cannot _make them_ like Julia because that's not how it works, trying to convince them is counterproductive ... and the only thing that we can do is to be patient and improve.
